text: "We?" Meaning you and me? Have we met, Mister...
... we didn't.

Are you going along?
But it's a highly delicate affair. A few molecules off and the vapor point crashes. Poof. It's gone. All of it.
Captain. You didn't have to come to me. I would've been happy to go to you.
Die?
Don't be so sure.
Full circle.
I hear you're sending an away team down to the surface.
I mean... if you don't go on this mission...

Is that a clipper ship?
Is this some kind of a joke?
It's a Tzartak aperitif. Very, very touchy.
Let me guess. My father sent you. Well, you tell him I've still got a lot more listening to do --

Mister Clemens, why do I suspect you're not one of them?
Mister Data. Of course.  Excuse us, but we have so much to catch up on...
No, you don't look like the joking type.
Perhaps a great deal more.
Please do.
Somebody getting married?
Starfleet captains usually don't accompany away teams...
That way, the moment the liquid touches the tongue, it evaporates. The flavor is carried entirely by the vapor.
That's why the Enterprise was sent back to Earth... I didn't realize...
The trick is to change the evaporation point of the main ingredient. You want the temperature where the liquid goes to vapor to be half a degree below the body temperature of your customer.
Then again, someone might say a diamond is still a diamond -- even if it is one among millions. It still shines as brightly.
This time you have to...

You just... do.
You remember when we first met?
... so when I finally got to the Head Surveyor... I found the location of your cavern. But you won't be able to get to it.
...thirsty...
...wait... stay a while... maybe they'll come for you...
But... I have to wait... almost five hundred years...  And when we meet... I won't be able to tell you about this, will I?
Clemens.
Data... so far I've been able to do everything you asked me to. But do you really expect me to get you into a high-security military installation?
Do I know you?

General Mallory is usually a stickler for the rules... but I happen to know that his wife thinks she's a singer. So I told him she simply must perform at my next gathering... and the rules just... disappeared.
He's been driving me crazy. He watches the house, follows me down the street asking questions -- I'd bet you anything he got in here and took your -- whatever you said.
History has to fulfill itself. Even Picard knew that.
I keep telling you, there is no plot --
I'll see you in five hundred years, Picard.
If I tell you what happened in that cavern, it would affect any decision you're about to make. I can't do that. I won't do that.

Mister Clemens... shame on you.

There you are! I have good news -- we can get into the Presidio --
There's been a blood feud between two branches of the family. He doesn't acknowledge me.
We... become friends...
Well... this is more interesting than giving tea dances.
What happened... ?
What?
What?
Where'd... everybody go... ?
Whoa... everything's spinning...
Yes.
You know me...
You know... so much about me...
You stayed here... for that... ?
You're still here...
Always room at the bar for another broken heart.
Exactly.
His head.

I'm taking care of myself these days.

Me personally?
No, his head. I'm attracted to bald men.
No, you're different.
No.
Seriously.
Yes, I can tell you that.
Yes.

It is not the end.

You start on Friday -- two shows a night, matinee on Wednesday.

Did he ever tell you why we were so close?
I hope I'm not imposing.

Then I'm not going to tell you either. But it was beyond friendship, beyond family... and I will let him go. You must, too.  There can only be one Captain.

They like you, Riker. They trust you. But they don't believe anyone can save them.

I don't blame you -- it's beautiful.

No, I don't mean that. I mean when you look there don't you see your future?

Oh?
Sure I do... all the time.

That's why I'm here.
There's nothing like a dish of Delovian souffle.

Where do they say?
You're going to be leaving soon.

Careful, if you place me too high on a pedestal, you won't be able to reach me.
Dreams can be dangerous.
I didn't say that. There's nothing wrong with a line. It's like a knock on the door.
I know that sensation.
I'm not sending you away.
It isn't supposed to.
Just because a girl runs out, doesn't mean she's not hoping you'll follow.
Maybe I do think it's a line.
Me too.
Of me?
Oh, there will be others -- but, the next time you feel love will be different. Each time is different.
Shut up, kid.  Now tell me more about my eyes.
Tell her about her eyes.
That seems simple enough.
Yes it would.
You won't find a better dish of chocolate on Thalos or Daled Four.
You're right.
... terrorizing one race after another... teasing them like helpless animals... delighting at the fear of your victims...
Begging. You're a pitiful excuse for a human and the only way you're going to survive is by the charity of others.
Calamarain...
Get used to it, Q.
He's human.
How the mighty have fallen.
I heard you were drummed out of the continuum.
Is that right?

Just one of the boys, huh?
You could learn a few things from this one.
"Truth", "beauty"... works for a lot of things.
Am I disturbing you?

Everyone's talking about you.
For people like you and me... who lose our homes... that's how life feels sometimes...
Good. You look like someone who wants to be disturbed.
Guinan. I keep the bar. I listen.
Guinan. I tend the bar. I listen.
Heard you'd been grounded.
I was in serious trouble once. More than I could handle alone.
I've always found that truth is in the eye of the beholder.
If you wanted to be alone, you would've stayed in your quarters. Only reason to come here is to be around people.
Including yourself.
My people lost their homeworld too.
Never know until you try.
No you wouldn't.
Not important now. Not yet. What is important is that I'd still be caught up in it to this day... if I hadn't trusted one man...
Really.
She can go right back to her quarters when she's done.
She's my friend.
So what do you feel like talking about?
So you sit alone in crowded rooms staring at your drink.
Sounds like someone I'd like to meet.
Sure you do.
The captain obviously thought she'd be valuable on this mission.
They say you never told anyone the truth about Galon Two. You didn't even defend yourself at the court martial.
Too late. You just made one.
Uh-huh.
You go out of your way to torture yourself... You work so hard at it, you've gotta love it.
You kind of enjoy it, don't you?
You're not like any Starfleet officer I ever met.  This might be the start of an interesting friendship.
You're one of those people who's got their poles reversed... you take a little unscrambling, but I've had a lot of practice.
You've been looking at your drink all night. How's the view?
Your fault.

A lot.

Almost.
Are you trying to say some nanites are on the loose?
Cute couple.
He wouldn't listen.
I run a clean place here.
I've never been very good at being confined to quarters. Any of my husbands would testify to that.
Just one.
Not in a species of listeners.
Pull up a stool, Wesley.

Well, it's taken a few hundred years or so but I've brought him around.

They all look for that one star, the one they call home... doesn't matter how far away it is... everyone still looks.  You're Worf's parents?
Worf... he never had prune juice until he came in here... now he can't get enough of it...
You don't think so? Look at him now... I think that's pretty special...
You ought to write a book.
Computer problem, huh...

Maybe it was your old VISOR...
Not what you hoped for, huh?

So... you met a computer-simulated female...
Take a hard look through your VISOR, La Forge... see her for who she really is... not what you want her to be.
The VISOR you wore on the holodeck with her.
Uh-huh...
We all fall in love with our fantasies, from time to time, La Forge...
Yes...
You saw exactly what you wanted to see in the holodeck... Sure, the computer made it look like her, added personality... but when it came to your relationship together, you filled in the blanks...
You're gonna wear that uniform out if you keep swatting at it...

Are you kidding? He was the only member of the family with a sense of humor. But no one ever stayed around him long enough to realize it... except me. My mother says I take after him. I probably do. Because the idea of "fitting in" repels me, too.
Are you sure?
Get it yourself.
He's imaginative.
He's not much for talking.
I give him his warm milk and let him be.
I just do.
If I had the feeling that nobody wanted to be around me, I'd probably be late and nervous too.
Not that I've seen.
Reminds me of Terkim. My mother's brother. A kind of family misfit. Everybody told me to stay away from him. Bad influence.
Terkim.
Warm milk helps you sleep, La Forge. You should try it. What's that got to do with Barclay?
Yes, I know him... comes in here, stands at the bar, doesn't say much... always orders a warm milk.
You engineering types don't appreciate imagination... ?
About the Borg...
And if I hold it too high, you lunge under it. Let's face it -- you're just better at this than I am.
And then... I found myself standing there, staring at him. Curiosity, I figured... just curiosity.
Aren't you just a bit surprised by him?
But thanks to you, there aren't many of us. We're scattered around the galaxy... we have no home... we don't even have each other.
Fine. But unless you talk to him -- at least once -- you might find that decision harder to live with than you realize.
How so?
Hugh?
I don't know what made me go see him. La Forge told me I should, but I said no.
I don't think I like this sport.
I hear they gave you a name.
I hear we have a guest on board.
I know. But... when you talk to him... face to face... can you honestly say you have no doubts?
I thought I understood you, Picard. But I don't understand this.
I was thinking about how you said my foil was dipping the other day... maybe I should do some exercises... build up a little strength in my arm...
I wouldn't have anything to say.
I've got news for you. It isn't. Some of my ancestors resisted the Borg, when you came to assimilate us. A few escaped.
If you're going to use this person --
If you're going to use this person to destroy his race, don't you think you should look him in the eye once before you do it?  Besides... I'm not so sure he is Borg anymore.
Is that wise?
La Forge gave it to him. His name's Hugh. And he's lonely.
No -- I think I'm asking you to persuade me.
No, I don't wish. But that's what you people do.
No, thanks.
No...
Not to mention tending bar...
Okay, so now you have a Borg named Hugh...
Picard... I want to hear you say that you're sure -- that what you're doing is right.
Resistance is futile. Right?
They'll be coming, you know that. You, of all people, know that.
This "kid's" big brothers are going to hunt us down. They won't rest until they have him back. And they'll destroy us in the process -- without any of this soul-searching you're going through.
Well... you don't look so tough.
Well? Aren't you going to tell me I have to be assimilated?
What... ?
Why not?
Yes. Did you know he has a name?
You felt sorry for me. Look what it got you.
You named a Borg...
You sure? Looks like you're all set for a quiet evening.
You're the second person today that's talked about this Borg as if he were a lost child...
All the time. When I get scared... or confused... or I need help. The way I see it, you don't ever have to lose your imaginary friend.

But the best thing about it was that I could curl up and lie on its furry stomach. It had the deepest, softest purr you've ever heard... it put me to sleep every night...  That razor beast was a good friend.
But?
Hello there. Are you looking for someone?
How about two glasses of Papalla juice... with extra bubbles.
How so?
I don't know about that. I was just telling Clara about my imaginary friend.
I see... a Samarian coral fish... with its fins unfolded...
I think someone's lost her way...
I was just talking with Clara and Isabella.
It was a Tarcassian razor beast. It had dark brown fur, gold eyes... huge spiny wings... It could fly so fast that no one could see it... except me.
It was... especially when it smiled.
It wasn't a he.
It wasn't a she.
Let me guess... about a little girl and her imaginary friend.
Maybe because when I was your age, I had an invisible friend, too.
No... first it was a fish... now I see a Mintonian sailing ship...
Oh, no?

One juice...
Over the years, its body kind of faded away. What was left was more of an idea than a thing.  I don't talk to it nearly as much as I used to.

See you later, Clara... Isabella.
Something wrong with the cake?

Well... they tend to get very preoccupied with grown-up things.

Too sweet, huh?
Well, don't look at me.

I can do that.

Too bad.  Better hours.

You know, I always thought so myself. Maybe I ought talk to Picard, what do you think?
You want to talk about it?
You were just being human...

Emotions. They're such slippery, contradictory things. It's a wonder any of us ever crawled out of the oceans, or swung down out of the trees.
Good luck, sir.

Coming up.

Security to Ten-Forward... right away.

No, they're touching lips. Kissing.

Sort of a work-study program...

A lot of things are contagious. Most of them aren't funny either.

Bring new jokes...
Forget it. Try another joke.
I can see that.
I've used it before. Everybody else at least smiles. It's you, Data.
It was funny.

Okona is right.

Whoa, slow down. Now Data, there's just you and me here and nobody is going to know what we talked about. My job here places me under some obligations, like a vow of secrecy. I can't repeat anything I hear or see. Now the obligation of the patron is to tell the truth, otherwise I'm being placed under a commitment to keep a secret about "nothing." That's not fair. It's called wasted honor. You understand?
You mean when he tells a joke.  That's it, isn't it? You don't have any idea what a joke is.

Bridge, this is Ten-Forward.

I'm here. I can see the other ship.

Meaning?
None other.

Q -- don't do this!

Q has set a series of events in motion. Your contact with the Borg came long before it should. When you're ready, it might be possible to establish a relationship with them, but now -- now, you are only raw material to them. And since they are aware of your existence...
They are a mixture of organic and artificial life that has been developed over a thousand centuries.
They never do that as individuals. It's just not their way. When they decide to come, they will come in force. They do nothing piecemeal.
They will learn -- adapt. That's their great advantage.
We had some dealings.
What?
Yes.
Yes.
Yes. My people encountered them a century ago. Our cities were destroyed -- our people scattered across the galaxy. They are called the Borg -- protect yourself or they will destroy you.
You can depend on it.
You don't, at least to my knowledge nobody has so far.
Mmmm-hmmmm.
Only if you're ready.
So's my father.

But other Klingons feel like laughing. What does that say about you... ?
Good game.  Hey, don't feel bad... I was doing this years before you were born.

How is he, by the way? Your son.
I'm sure I heard you laugh once... I liked it...
Must be tough for a little guy like that... living with humans, being Klingon... it has to get confusing sometimes...
No, it won't. But the time will come when he'll have to find out what it really means to be Klingon...  Just as the time has come now for you, Worf.
Not true. Not true at all. You may not laugh. But believe me, I've heard some Klingon belly laughs that could shake a room.
Oh, that's right and you're not. You're all Klingon. Except you don't laugh.

Sure. I like to keep my eye sharp.

Because part of me does...

I can see her.. in my mind... asking me a question...  And then it's gone...
I don't know how I know. I just do.  I remember it.
I know that... but I also know I'm right.
I know. But I also know she was on that ship -- and she wasn't a child.  And Picard... you sent her there.
Is that what you really think? Or is there some part of you... that wonders?
That's all I have. But I listen to it... and you should do the same.

Word travels fast. I heard that Tasha Yar's daughter is on the Romulan ship.

'Fraid that's the last of it. Next rainfall in a hundred and sixty three days.
-- Data honey, I don't think it would've helped. That joke chilled my blood.
-- Maybe it's the birds.

Are you really going down to see Ira Graves? The Ira Graves?
Birds are considered to have boring personalities. They just sit around and eat seed all day. Maybe squawk once in a while. Boring.
Don't feel too bad, Data. Humor is subjective.
In fact, there's only one thing birds do that's funny, but you couldn't put that in a joke and keep it tasteful.  Now chickens. Chickens are funny.
It wasn't meant to be, Data.
It's a challenge, but I'm trying.

This I gotta hear.
But is it more than you hoped?
But you were afraid.
Careful, if you place me too high on a pedestal, you won't be able to reach me.

Of me?

That seems simple enough.

Ah.

Beverly.

But this was different.
But... I didn't.
Comfortable?
Do I have to break my leg before you tell me what happened?
Do you think Reyga killed himself?
Do you think there's a murderer on the Enterprise?
Doctor... are you angry?
Don't you think anyone would have? Maybe you're being a little hard on yourself.
For me? What's the occasion?
For two hours you've been moping around, feeling sorry for yourself...

I don't want to see Selar. I always see you. I'm particular about my doctors.
I need a doctor.
I've heard every word you said.
I've never been to a formal inquiry.
If I had to hazard a guess... I'd say that when you're dealing with a patient... you feel like you're in control.
If you're angry -- maybe you'll stop moping and do something.
My elbow.
No?
So you invited the scientists on board... to listen to this Doctor Reyga...
Somebody's birthday?
Sort of a scientific diplomat.
Thank you, Doctor... it looks like a great racquet. But you see... I don't play tennis. Never have.
That would do it, all right.
That's how I did it. Geordi kept hitting to my backhand at the net...
That's my favorite kind.
That's right. You could be relieved of duty.
Then what are you going to do about it?
